name: Jai Field

honours.Challenge Cup: Final at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, contributing to the win against the Huddersfield Giants.
honours.Super League: Grand Final to his tally, starting at full back in Wigan’s win over Catalans Dragons at Old Trafford in 2023.
honours.World Club Challenge: , Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

bio: In an outstanding year for Field, he was awarded Player of the Year and Players’ Player of the Year at the annual Club awards, he won Broadcast & Writers association Player of the Year and was also shortlisted for the 2022 Man of Steel award, picking up numerous Player and Try of the month awards throughout the season.
career_highlights: 2021 Player Bio Known for his lightning quick feet and tricky ball skills, Field began his career at St George Illawarra before moving to Parramatta Eels.
2017 and 2019, he joined Parramatta Eels in 2020 where he made six appearances.
2020 on a two-year deal starting from 2021.
2021 season, the 23-year-old was assigned the No.
2021 Round 1 win over Leigh Centurions, but it was cut short after he suffered a hamstring injury in the first half.
2021 but suffered a further injury a few games later, this time on his groin and did not feature again in 2021.
2022, Field announced that he had signed a two-year deal with the Club with an option of a third year meaning the Aussie will remain in cherry & white until at least the end of 2024.
2022, Field scored a try in the second half of the Challenge Cup Final at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, contributing to the win against the Huddersfield Giants.
2022, the second most by any player that season.
2022 Man of Steel award, picking up numerous Player and Try of the month awards throughout the season.
2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

name: Abbas Miski

honours.Challenge Cup: , League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

bio: In 2019, Miski signed for Black Workers Sea Eagles, a feeder team for Manly before being called into Manly Warringah Sea Eagles first team to make his debut in 2019, in the same year he was top try scorer for Black Workers with 12 tries. Miski was called in to first team squad for Manly’s final game of the season in 2020, scoring two tries in a loss.
career_highlights: 2022 Player Bio A prolific finisher on the wing, Miski shot up in the ranks in a Top Try Scoring season in 2023.
2017 World Cup and most recently the rescheduled RLWC2021 held in England.
2020, scoring two tries in a loss.
2021 season, where in 13 appearances for Broncos, he scored 12 tries before he joined Wigan for the 2022 season on a three-year deal.
2022 and scored his first try for the Club against Wakefield Trinity at the DW Stadium on Easter Monday 2022.
2023, Miski spend some time on loan before being called into the first team following some injuries.
2023, lifting both the League Leaders’ Shield and the Super League trophy.
2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

name: Adam Keighran

honours.Super League: move came in 2023, as he joined Super League side Catalans Dragons on a one-year deal. He caught the eye of many as the Dragons launched an impressive season, going on to reach the Super League Grand Final.
honours.World Club Challenge: , League Leaders’ Shield and Super League.

bio: Playing his trade as a Centre in 2023, Keighran joined Wigan Warriors on a two-year deal where he lifted a treble of trophies in his first season with the Club – winning the World Club Challenge, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League.
career_highlights: 2024 Player Bio Adam Keighran joins the Warriors ahead of the 2024 season, after a successful season with Catalans Dragons in 2023.
2019, going on to make nine appearances over two seasons.
2021 after signing for the Roosters, where he scored four tries and kicked 35 goals in 17 games for Trent Robinson’s side.
2023, as he joined Super League side Catalans Dragons on a one-year deal.

name: Jake Wardle

honours.Challenge Cup: , League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.
honours.World Club Challenge: , Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

bio: Halifax-born Wardle is an England international having made his try-scoring debut in a win over the Combined Nations All Stars in 2022. He has also represented England Knights’ on one occasion in a win over France in 2022.
career_highlights: 2023 Player Bio A proven try scorer and versatile outside back, Wardle joined the Warriors in 2023 on a three-year deal.
2023, as well as winning the Harry Sunderland trophy for Man of the Match in the 2023 Super League Grand Final.
2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

name: Liam Marshall

honours.Challenge Cup: Final against Hull FC at Wembley Stadium.
honours.Super League: Grand Final that saw Wigan crowned Champions.
honours.World Club Challenge: , Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

bio: He returned to the side in 2019, becoming Wigan’s top try scorer for the season with 17 in 24 games and Marshall had a bright start to 2020, but his season was cut short once again, this time with a knee ligament injury sustained against Castleford in late August. He appeared ten times, scoring six tries.
career_highlights: 2017 Player Bio Renowned for his acrobatic diving style when scoring tries, Liam Marshall is an entertainer on the pitch and a recognised try scorer in the first team.
2016, scoring 20 tries in 22 appearances.
2017 season and he had a dream debut campaign, playing 24 times, scoring 23 tries and being named joint Wigan Warriors Young Player of the Year.
2017 Challenge Cup Final against Hull FC at Wembley Stadium.
2018 after a string of stand-out performances.
2021 after a 10-month spell on the sidelines recovering from the ACL injury and went on to make 16 appearances, scoring 7 tries.
2022 and in October 2022, Marshall also announced that he had signed a new 3-year deal that would see the winger remain at his hometown Club until 2025.
2023 continued to be a strong year for the winger, who appeared 29 times across the year – scoring 24 tries.
2023 Super League Grand Final that saw Wigan crowned Champions.
2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

name: Bevan French
bio: French was part of the Warriors team who completed the Grand Slam in 2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season. He also made history as the first player to win the Player of the Match awards in the same season (Bill Ashurst Medal in the World Club Challenge, Lance Todd Trophy in the Challenge Cup and the inaugural Rob Burrow Award in the Super League Grand Final.)
career_highlights: 2019 Player Bio Renowned for his electric pace and dancing feet, Bevan French can play a variety of positions in the backline and in the halves.
2016 and scored 35 tries overall.
2019 season after being granted a release from Parramatta.
2019 and scored six tries.
2020 season, touching down 17 tries in 21 games in all competitions and alongside fellow Warrior Liam Farrell, he was named in the 2020 Betfred Super League Dream Team at full back.
2020 and shortlisted for the 2020 Steve Prescott Man of Steel.
2021 and returned home to Australia to complete rehabilitation before exercising his additional year option, returning to the Warriors for pre-season ahead of the 2022 season.
2022 and his fantastic work in the 2022 season saw him selected in the Super League Dream Team for a second time in his career.
2022 Super League awards as he finished the year with 31 tries.
2023, French was an ever-present, playing in all 32 available matches across the year.
2023, and was named in the Super League Dream Team for a third time, in a third different position – this time at Stand Off.
2023, after an exceptional year for the Warriors.
2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

name: Harry Smith

honours.Challenge Cup: Final, scoring a try in the first half, kicking 2/3 conversions and a putting through a grubber kick to set-up Liam Marshall’s winning try.
honours.World Club Challenge: , Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

bio: The half back’s rise through the Academy saw him become captain of the Under-19s, as well as a three-time Grand Final winner (2017, 2018 and 2019) and the 2018 Under-19s Player of the Year. Smith was influential as he captained England’s Academy side to a 2-0 series win against Australia in December 2018.
career_highlights: 2000 Heritage Number 1099 Debut 06.

2017, 2018 and 2019) and the 2018 Under-19s Player of the Year.

2019, coming off the bench and scoring a try in a 46-12 win over Catalans Dragons at the DW Stadium.
2020, making 17 appearances, scoring four tries and converting two drop goals.
2021 saw Smith’s career go one step further, the Half back played in every game for Wigan, a total of 28.
2022 Challenge Cup Final, scoring a try in the first half, kicking 2/3 conversions and a putting through a grubber kick to set-up Liam Marshall’s winning try.
2022, making 24 appearances in 2022, scoring 7 tries, 94 goals and 2 match-winning drop goals.
2022 as he came off the bench as England beat Fiji 50-0.
2023, Smith made the number 7 shirt his own.
2024, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

name: Ethan Havard

honours.Challenge Cup: Final, Havard came off the bench to join the winning side against the Huddersfield Giants at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium. The prop-forward made 22 appearances in 2022, scoring 5 tries in his best scoring return for the Club to date.
honours.Super League: Grand Final win over Catalans Dragons.

bio: Havard impressed in his debut season as a full professional, making 11 appearances before having his season cut short with an ankle injury. He picked up the first silverware of his career with Wigan’s League Leaders’ Shield success in November. The 2020 season ended with personal success too, with the young forward being named Wigan’s Young Player of the Year at the Club’s End of Season Awards Night.
career_highlights: 2000 Heritage Number 1097 Debut 18.
2019 Player Bio A 23-year-old prop forward who was born in Sofia, Bulgaria before growing up in Wigan to later join the Club’s Academy where he would progress to the first team.
2017 and was awarded The Riversiders (Wigan Warriors Supporters Club) Under-16s Player of the Year.
2018, he moved up to the Under-19s level in Wigan’s Academy and played a part in the Grand Final winning squad that beat Leeds Rhinos 14-6 at the DW Stadium in September.
2019, the 6ft 3 forward made his professional debut for the Club in the 46-16 win over Wakefield Trinity in July.
2020 season ended with personal success too, with the young forward being named Wigan’s Young Player of the Year at the Club’s End of Season Awards Night.
2021, making 25 appearances and also scoring first try in Cherry & White against Warrington Wolves at the Dacia Magic Weekend in Newcastle.
2022 Challenge Cup Final, Havard came off the bench to join the winning side against the Huddersfield Giants at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium.
2022, scoring 5 tries in his best scoring return for the Club to date.
2023 saw Havard troubled with injuries, as such he only played 18 games, scoring two tries.
2023, that will see him stay with the Club until at least the end of 2027.
2023 Super League Grand Final win over Catalans Dragons.
2024 Super League Grand Final.

name: Brad O'Neill

honours.World Club Challenge: and Challenge Cup to his honours in 2024.

bio: In March 2021, he played for the first time in over 20 months – gaining first team experience for the Warriors, as he featured in the pre-season friendly against Salford Red Devils before signing for Widnes Vikings on a four-week loan deal in April 2021. His spell with the Betfred Championship club was extended and he played nine games and scored two tries in his time there. He also made an average of 42 tackles per game.
career_highlights: 2002 Heritage Number 1112 Debut 24.
2021 Player Bio A product of Wigan’s Academy system, Brad O’Neill has become a regular name on the Warriors teamsheet, inspiring Wigan to Challenge Cup victory at Hooker in 2022.
2017, O’Neill signed for Wigan’s Scholarship system and played two seasons for the Under-16s team.
2019 and also represented Lancashire Academy twice.
2020 – a year which saw all Academy games suspended due to the Covid-19 pandemic.
2022, O’Neill secured his first Challenge Cup win against the Huddersfield Giants at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, coming into the squad a few weeks prior in place of Sam Powell.
2022, and was influential in Wigan’s Challenge Cup run as starting hooker in both the Semi Final and Final.
2023 was a key season for the young hooker, who found a more consistent run of games for the Warriors.

name: Luke Thompson

honours.Challenge Cup: in a starting appearance at Wembley Stadium, as well as adding a League Leaders’ Shield and Super League Trophy to his tally with the Warriors in his first season with the Club.

bio: He signed for Wigan in October 2023 on a four-year deal and boulstered the Warriors forward pack in the 2024 season. The forward missed Wigan’s Betfred World Club Challenge game through a failed HIA but lifted the Betfred Challenge Cup in a starting appearance at Wembley Stadium, as well as adding a League Leaders’ Shield and Super League Trophy to his tally with the Warriors in his first season with the Club.
career_highlights: 2024 Player Bio A new member of the forward pack, Luke Thompson joins the Warriors for the 2024 season from Canterbury Bulldogs.
2018 and 2019 following two uncompromising seasons.

2021, with a further 13 in 2022.

name: Junior Nsemba
bio: Nsemba was a treble winner with the Warriors in 2024 lifting the Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League trophy. He was also named Young Player of the Year at the annual Super League Awards, whilst also claiming the same award at the Clubs’ 2024 awards.

name: Liam Farrell

honours.Challenge Cup: winner with Wigan – with successes in 2011 (vs Leeds Rhinos), 2013 (vs Hull FC) and 2022 (vs Huddersfield Giants).
honours.World Club Challenge: squad that beat Cronulla Sharks at the DW Stadium, completing his trophy set.

bio: The 2020 season marked Farrell’s testimonial year for Wigan. The Warriors took on Leeds Rhinos in his testimonial friendly fixture, taking place at the DW Stadium ahead of the Betfred Super League season at the end of January. A fantastic 2020 campaign then lay ahead for the second row, who appeared 21 times for Wigan, scoring ten tries – helping the Warriors clinch their first silverware since 2018, lifting the League Leaders’ Shield.
career_highlights: 2010 Player Bio A one-Club man who is one of the most decorated players in the Wigan team – winning all there is to claim in the game – he is now Captain of the Club.
2010 and went on to complete a dream first season playing 23 games, including the Grand Final win over St Helens.
2011 will be part of club folklore.
2011 (vs Leeds Rhinos), 2013 (vs Hull FC) and 2022 (vs Huddersfield Giants).
2010 vs St Helens and 2013, 2016, 2018 vs Warrington Wolves and 2023 vs Catalans Dragons).
2013 World Cup and was an ever-present in the 2014 Four Nations Series.
2016 Grand Final and was also part of the 2017 World Club Challenge squad that beat Cronulla Sharks at the DW Stadium, completing his trophy set.
2019 under Adrian Lam – a season which saw him being named in the Super League Dream Team for the second time in his career (2015 was his first time).
2020 season marked Farrell’s testimonial year for Wigan.
2020 Betfred Super League Dream Team alongside teammate Bevan French.
2020 Steve Prescott Man of Steel.
2020 End of Season Awards evening, as Lam highlighted the Englishman’s professionalism on and off the field in a challenging season for all.
2021, including a stint at Centre, grabbing 9 tries along the way.
2021 also saw Farrell named in the Super League Dream Team for a fourth time (2015, 2019, 2020) as well as picking up Player’s Player of the Year at the Warriors End of Season Awards evening.
2022, Liam Farrell was announced as the new Club Captain and went on to Captain his side to more silverware in 2023.
2023, having featured 30 times and scoring 9 tries in the campaign which saw Wigan lift the League Leaders’ Shield and beat Catalans Dragons 10-2 in the Betfred Super League Grand Final.
2024, Farrell captained Wigan to an historic Grand Slam, winning the World Club Challenge, Challenge Cup, League Leaders’ Shield and Super League all in the same season.

bio: Having made his Betfred Super League debut for the Dragons against Leeds Rhinos in 2022, his performances earned him a call up for France against England in 2023. Chan scored one try in 12 appearances for Catalans before joining the Warriors ahead of the 2024 campaign.

name: Taylor Kerr
bio: Kerr, who scored five tries in 13 appearances for the Academy in 2023, represented Lancashire in their Academy Origin Series win over Yorkshire in which he scored a try in the second clash in Hull.
career_highlights: 2006 Player Bio Kerr started and recorded an assist for St John Fisher in the Year 7 Champion Schools Final at Wembley Stadium.

name: Nathan Lowe
bio: An impressive 2023 Academy campaign saw the centre accumulate 64 points [12 tries and eight goals] from 12 starts, which was rewarded with a place on the First Teams pre-season camp to Portugal in 2024.
career_highlights: 2005 Player Bio Lowe made an instant impact in youth rugby as he won a clean sweep of awards at Leigh East, before he later went on to represent Wigan St Judes.

name: Lukas Mason
bio: The second rower has progressed through the junior system at Siddal, Clock Face Miners and Orrell St James.

name: Noah Hodkinson
bio: The full-back, who played his amateur rugby at Hindley ARLFC, was included on the First Team’s pre-season camp in Portugal ahead of the 2024 season.
career_highlights: 2005 Player Bio Bolton-born Hodkinson signed his first Warriors contract with the Scholarship programme in 2021.

name: Kian McDermott
bio: Wigan-born McDermott signed his first contract with the Warriors Scholarship programme in 2021 after progressing through the ranks at Wigan St Patricks.

name: George Hirst
bio: The Batley-born forward started his rugby league career at local side Dewsbury Moor aged nine before impressive performances at Almondbury Spartans in the Yorkshire Men’s League led to Hirst signing for Oldham in 2023.
career_highlights: 2001 Player Bio George Hirst joined Wigan Warriors from Oldham RLFC in October 2024 on a two-year deal with a further year option.
2024 season under the guidance of head coach Sean Long.

name: Christian Wade
bio: On his return to rugby union, Wade played for Racing 92 in France before joining Gloucester for the 2024/2025 season. Wade scored 11 tries during the Premiership season, including two in his final appearance which took his total in the competition to 93 tries – eight behind Chris Ashton’s all-time record.
career_highlights: 2025 Player Bio Wigan Warriors announced the signing of Christian Wade on a short-term deal ahead of the 2025 Good Friday Derby at The Brick Community Stadium.
2013 tour to Australia.
2018, Wade left rugby union to pursue an NFL career for the Buffalo Bills – taking advantage of the NFL’s International Player Pathway Programme.
